name: Zaleplon
summary: Zaleplon is a nonbenzodiazepine hypnotic used for the short-term treatment of insomnia, particularly for difficulty falling asleep.
description: Zaleplon, marketed under the brand name Sonata, is a pyrazolopyrimidine-class nonbenzodiazepine hypnotic indicated for short-term management of insomnia characterized by difficulty with sleep initiation. It acts as a selective agonist at the benzodiazepine site of the GABA-A receptor complex, enhancing GABA-mediated inhibition in the CNS. Zaleplon has an ultra-short half-life, making it useful for sleep onset problems but not for maintaining sleep.

off_label_uses: Middle-of-the-night awakenings (with at least 4 hours of planned sleep remaining)
contraindications: Known hypersensitivity to zaleplon or formulation components
History of complex sleep behaviors after taking hypnotics
monitoring_required: Signs of misuse, abuse, or dependence

items: Short-term treatment of insomnia characterized by difficulty falling asleep

sections.text: Binds selectively to the benzodiazepine site of the GABA-A receptor complex, enhancing the inhibitory effects of GABA and promoting sleep onset.

adult.oral: 10 mg immediately before bedtime; for some patients, 5 mg may be sufficient. Maximum 20 mg/day. For middle-of-the-night awakening, 5–10 mg if ≥4 hours remain before planned waking.

sections.text: Rapid onset within ~15–30 minutes; very short half-life (~1 hour), with duration limited to sleep initiation.

other: Can cause complex sleep behaviors including sleepwalking, sleep-driving, and engaging in other activities while not fully awake
Risk of dependence and withdrawal; use the lowest effective dose for the shortest duration
May cause next-day impairment, particularly if insufficient sleep time remains

sections.pregnancy: Limited data; use only if benefit outweighs risk
sections.lactation: Unknown excretion in human milk; caution advised
sections.geriatrics: Use lower starting dose (5 mg) due to increased sensitivity and risk of falls

sections.text: If used regularly for more than 1–2 weeks, taper gradually to reduce risk of withdrawal and rebound insomnia.

items: Best suited for patients with difficulty initiating sleep rather than maintaining sleep
Ultra-short half-life reduces next-day sedation compared to some other hypnotics
Can be used for middle-of-the-night awakenings if ≥4 hours remain before planned waking
